newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-Australian Labor, Democrats may unite on native title.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-Australian Labor, Democrats may unite on native title.

text.p: Australian non-government parties may combine to force changes to the government's proposed native land ownership legislation, opposition Labor spokesman Daryl Melham said on Monday.

Labor and Australian Democrats members of a parliamentary committee backed a report calling for changes to the government's proposed legislation, which would itself alter the native title system set up by the former Labor government.
"(Democrats leader Cheryl) Kernot signed off on all aspects of the Labor minority report," Melham told reporters.
The government does not control the Senate. Labor and the Democrats can get the bill amended if three of the other four Independent and Greens senators join them.
Melham said under the government's bill approvals for land developments could be delayed by Aborigines pursuing their common law rights through the courts.
The minority report recommended against the bill's:
-- Registration test for native title applications that would make them more difficult to administer by the Native Title Tribunal;
-- Denying the right to negotiate over development proposals by applicants who do not pass a test for registration;
-- Providing for a once-only right to negotiate over development proposals, effectively covering exploration and mining, and denying native title holders the use of the land;
-- Allowing the minister to intervene in certain circumstances, effectively denying the right to negotiate;
-- Giving the minister authority to permit a development on native title land;
-- Limiting mediation to matters that could be litigated in a court;
-- Limiting the right to negotiate to four months from six months before arbitration over mining could begin;
-- Ending Aborigines' right to stop expedited processing of developments by claiming merely spiritual interference, rather than physical interference;
-- Authorisation of the minister to recognise or deny recognition of native title representative bodies on grounds that the minority report called inadequate.
Melham said he would raise the minority recommendations with his Labor party colleagues shortly.
The bill, the Native Title Amendment Bill will be debated in the lower house of parliament, the House of Representatives, on December 2.
